section.title: Overview
section.p:
eXist is an Open Source native XML database featuring efficient, index-based XQuery processing, automatic indexing, extensions for full-text search,
XUpdate
support and tight integration with existing XML development tools. The database implements the current XQuery 1.0 working draft as of November, 2003 (for the core syntax, some details already following later versions), with the exception of the XML schema related features.

XQuery support in eXist makes it possible to write entire web applications with just XQuery and XSLT. XQuery files can be directly passed to the database, using either the XQueryServlet, the XQueryGenerator for Cocoon or the REST-style API (see Developer's Guide ).
Additional features: Java binding, fulltext-search functions, modules in XQuery and Java, extension modules for HTTP support, database manipulation and XSL transformations.

To avoid memory-intensive document tree traversals during query processing, eXist uses an efficient index structure which is based on a numerical indexing scheme for identifying XML nodes in the index. The database is lightweight, completely written in Java and may be easily deployed in a number of ways, running either as a stand-alone server process, inside a servlet-engine or directly embedded into an application.
For a summary of eXist's features please have a look at the feature sheet .

section.title: Download
section.p:
eXist is released to the public under the terms of the
GNU LGPL
license.

eXist may be downloaded either as a package containing the complete distribution or as a web application archive (war-file). Download the war-file if you want to install eXist into an existing servlet-engine or write your own web application. To get started, we suggest downloading the installer or the zip package. Both contain a ready-to-run webserver (Jetty).
The distribution includes source code and all required third party libraries. The current version is 1.0beta2. For instructions on starting eXist, read the Quick Start Guide .

p.emphasis: If you are updating from a previous release, please read the update notes.

tr.td: Installer based on IzPack. Includes source. Run with java -jar eXist-snapshot-XXXXXX.jar .

Development snapshots reflect the current state of development. They are released on a regular basis whenever we think the CVS code is in a stable state and important new features or bug fixes should be made available to the community. The latest snapshot release can always be found on the
Sourceforge file release system. Concerning installation, there's no difference to a stable release.

Please note that development snapshots are not necessarily less stable than the latest "stable" release. Snapshots often contain important bug fixes which are not yet available in the stable release. There's also a risk that new bugs or regressions were introduced. However, we try to keep the snapshots as stable as possible. New features, bugs or problems will be announced via the mailing list and the Wiki.

warning.title: Health Warning
warning.p: The 1.0 beta2 release is truly ancient now. There were lots of bug fixes and feature enhancements during the past months, so using beta2 cannot be recommended any more. Please download a newer development snapshot. Recent development snapshots can be regarded as stable. A new official "stable" release is in preparation, but as usual, we lack the time to complete the documentation. Any help will be welcome!

tr.td: Installer based on IzPack. Highly recommended. Includes source. Run with java -jar eXist-1.0b2.jar .
Web application archive, ready to be installed into an existing servlet-engine like Tomcat or Jetty.

jEdit's XQuery plugin offers a comfortable interface to write and test XQueries from within jEdit. The plugin provides an adapter architecture to access different XQuery engines. Using the adapter for eXist, you can execute your XQuery directly from within jEdit. Follow the link to read more.

section.title: Community Support
section.p: The primary medium for asking questions, getting help or posting bug reports or fixes is the project mailing list. To subscribe/unsubscribe visit the mailing lists page on sourceforge.
The list archive can be found on the same page. However, most people find Gmane more convenient:
